content.question: The market for tomatoes is in equilibrium at the price of <math alttext="$10" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>$</mi><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, and quantity of <math alttext="50" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> tomatoes. If consumer surplus is <math alttext="$400" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>$</mi><mn>400</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and total economic surplus is <math alttext="$650" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>$</mi><mn>650</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, what is the producer surplus in the tomato market and why?

choices.label: The producer surplus is <math alttext="$0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>$</mi><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, because producer surplus is offset by the costs of producing tomatoes.
The producer surplus is <math alttext="$250" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>$</mi><mn>250</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, because the total surplus less what consumers receive must go to producers.

The producer surplus is <math alttext="Negative $400" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mo>−</mo><mrow><mi>$</mi><mn>400</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, because consumer and producer surplus must offset one another.

The producer surplus is <math alttext="$500" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>$</mi><mn>500</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, because the producer surplus is the equilibrium price times the equilibrium quantity <math alttext="equals, $10 times 50, equals $500" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>$</mi><mn>10</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>50</mn><mo>=</mo><mi>$</mi><mn>500</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.
The producer surplus is <math alttext="$650" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>$</mi><mn>650</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, because producer surplus and total economic surplus are always equal.

content.answer: The producer surplus is <math alttext="$250" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>$</mi><mn>250</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, because the total surplus less what consumers receive must go to producers.
